subject: Politics
title: Borders and Conflict
description: A micro-lesson that makes Borders and Conflict usable.

hook.text: Africa's borders were drawn by Europeans with rulers and pens. They split ethnic groups and ignited lasting conflicts.

buildup.text: Political borders rarely match ethnic, linguistic, or geographic lines. The mismatch causes tension.

discovery.text: The Sykes-Picot Agreement of 1916 carved up the Middle East. Its arbitrary lines still fuel conflict today.

twist.text: India and Pakistan were partitioned in 1947 along religious lines. It triggered one of history's deadliest migrations.

climax.text: Border disputes remain active worldwide. India-China, Israel-Palestine, and Russia-Ukraine all fight over lines.

punchline.text: Bad borders make bad neighbors. Most were drawn by someone else.

quiz.question: What was the Sykes-Picot Agreement?
options: A 1916 agreement that divided the Middle East into arbitrary borders
A peace treaty ending World War II
A trade agreement between France and Britain
